translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)🔽The Chapter of the Mango Grove
The Shorter Narada Birth Story
“You haven’t split the firewood,
and you haven’t fetched water.
You haven’t even lit the fire.
Why are you meditating so slowly?”
“I can’t bear to live in the wilderness.
I ask you to dismiss me.
Life in the wilderness is painful.
I want to go to the countryside.
Wherever I go from here,
in whatever country I live,
I will train in the conduct of a brahmin.
Please instruct me in that teaching.”
“If, having left the wilderness,
with its roots and fruits,
you prefer to live in the countryside,
then listen to this teaching from me.
Don’t frequent intoxicants,🔽and avoid the abyss.
Don’t sink in the mud,
but be careful when walking near snakes.”
“What is poison or an abyss
or mud for a celibate?
Who do you call a snake?
Please tell me this when asked.”
“Son, in the world,
intoxicants are called poison.
They’re delicious, fragrant, and attractive,
Like a delicious but bitter soup.
The Noble Ones say that poison,
is celibacy, Nārada.
Women in the world, dear sir,

analyzed: pamattam pamathenti tā  haranti yuvinaḥ citta
translated: make you lose your mindfulness;🔽They steal the mind of the young,
like a cat a sleeping bird.
This is said to be a pitfall,
for celibacy, Nārada.
Gain, fame, honor,
and worship in other families;
This is said to be a mire,
for celibacy, Nārada.🔽Dear sir, kings with their retinues

analyzed: āvasanti mahim ima  te tādise manussinde
translated: live on this earth;🔽They are great, dear Nārada,
to such human beings.
To the powerful lords,
one should not go under their feet;
This is said to be a snake,
for celibacy, Nārada.
When it is time to eat, for the sake of food,
to whatever house one goes;
If one knows there is wholesome there,
one should go there for alms.
Having entered another’s house,
for the sake of drink or food;
One should eat moderately, eat moderately,
and not be attached to form.
A cesspool, liquor, and a Kirāta,
and the seats in the assembly hall,
Avoid them from a distance,

analyzed: yāni iva visamam pathanti 🔽cūḍa nārada jātakam
translated: like a path that is uneven.”🔽The Jātaka of Cūḷanārada is the fourth.
